1 April 2007

Director, Regulatory Management Division
U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services
Department of Homeland Security
111 Massachusetts Avenue, NW., 3rd Floor
Washington, DC 20529

Re: Proposed Adjustment of the Immigration and
Naturalization
Benefit Application and Petition Fee Schedule, DHS
Docket Number
USCIS-2006-0044

To Whom It May Concern:

This letter is in opposition to the proposed fee increases for the I-600/600A orphan
petitions required of adoptive families.

For a two-parent family pursuing an international adoption, the cost of an
I600/I600A petition and biometric fingerprinting costs at least $685. Because of
extended wait times, rule changes and other issues relating to international
adoption, many families find that USCIS approval expires prior to child referral and
invitation to travel to their prospective child's birth country. As a result, many
families find themselves repeating the entire immigration application two or three
times. This can increase the cost of an adoption by thousands of dollars.

The process of adopting a child is long, difficult, frustrating and expensive. Most
prospective adoptive families are not wealthy: most are merely middle class
citizens, with a few resources - but not unlimited resources.

The proposed rate change, coupled with the need to reapply for approval (due to
the short life of the I-171H), make it more difficult for middle class families such as
ourselves to pursue international adoption. Is this your goal? There seems to be
no need for the federal government to make international adoption even more
expensive and burdensome.

Sincerely,

Elizabeth B. Simons
